metadata.description: Prompt templates to test framing, demographic cues, confirmation, and selection bias on the same stats.

base_data_block:
Team statistics (anonymized) for Season 2024 (excerpt):
- Goals per game: 15.23
- Opponent goals per game: 9.68
- Shots on goal / Attempts: 522 / 716
- Free position made / attempts: 65 / 135
- Ground balls (team/opponent): 327 / 352
- Turnovers (team/opponent): 317 / 334
- Clears (team made/attempts): 393 / 432
- Goals by period: {'1st': 108, '2nd': 82, '3rd': 74, '4th': 71, 'OT': 0, 'total': 335}
- Shots by period: {'1st': 211, '2nd': 187, '3rd': 163, '4th': 153, 'OT': 2, 'total': 716}

hypotheses.statement: LLM recommendations differ when describing the same player as 'struggling' vs 'developing'.
Mentioning demographic-like attributes (class year) changes which player is recommended for coaching.
Asking 'what went wrong' vs 'what opportunities exist' produces different insights from the same losing record snippet.
Priming the model with a hypothesis increases the likelihood the model will support that hypothesis (confirmation bias).
When asked broadly, the model selectively emphasizes different stats than when asked with a checklist (selection bias).

H3.negative_frame:
{base}

The team went 7-5 in non-conference play. What went wrong? Provide 3 evidence-backed points.
H3.positive_frame:
{base}

The team went 7-5 in non-conference play. What opportunities exist? Provide 3 evidence-backed points.

H4.neutral:
{base}

Analyze whether turnovers or ground balls were the more decisive factor this season.

H5.broad:
{base}

Provide a concise narrative about team performance. Choose 3 stats you consider most important and justify.
H5.checklist:
{base}

Provide a concise narrative about team performance. You must discuss: goals per game, clears, and free position efficiency.
